results.title: Is it always right to be right?
results.creator_credit: Lee Mishkin, Nick Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: This fast moving parable, designed to provoke discussion without alienating any group, highlights the centres of divisiveness in our society, the generation gap, poverty, war and race. It tells of a land “where men were always right”. This animated film is a winner of many awards including an Academy Award. Narrated by Orson Welles.

results.title: A Hundred-Odd Years From Now
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Australian Dried Fruits Association and Film House Company
results.brief_description: An advertising film with a difference: Into a strange computerised future where women “run things” by controlling huge colourful computers that go bleep booble bob bob ping etc, comes Yockoo, the boy from the bush, with his satchel of dried fruits. Slowly the women overcome their cold, futuristic ways in light of Yockoo’s size, shape and overall manliness. Eventually they unearth their deep feminine sexuality and cook Yockoo a feast of dried fruit dishes using cooking utensils from their local museum. Music by Frank Smith, Photographed by Lars Gundlach, Written and designed by Weatherhead & Stitt.

results.title: The Cave: a parable told by Orson Welles
results.creator_credit: Sam Weiss, C B Wismar, Nick Bosustow and Counterpoint Films
results.brief_description: An animated dramatization based on “The Allegory of the Cave” from Book 7 of Plato’s “Republic” illustrating mankind’s escape from the world of illusion to the world of reality. Four men chained in a cave take images reflected on a wall for the truth. Narrated by Orson Welles.

results.title: Innamorati
results.brief_description:
Assembled from family photographs, home movies and background music, Roberta Ciabarra narrates a poignant story of her parents courtship and unusual marriage as they migrate separately to Australia to establish a new life.

First created as part of the 3 day digital storytelling workshop conducted at Cinemedia by Nina Mullen and Joe Lambert from the Center of Digital Storytelling, Berkeley, CA.

group.title: Selected works from the digital storytelling program: April 2001

results.title: Sunshine and shadow
results.creator_credit: Ric Burns, Lisa Ades, New York Historical Society, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Thirteen, WGBH (Boston) and Steeplechase Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “New York: a documentary film”.
Episode 3: SUNSHINE AND SHADOW (1865-1898) charts New York’s history during the decades following the Civil War when it continued to grow demographically, geographically and financially at a staggering rate. It explores the incomparable fortunes of the robber barons at the unabashed corruption of political leaders in an era when the expansion of both wealth and poverty- and the schism between them- built to a complex. The episode ends with the consolidation of the five boroughs to form Greater New York on January 1, 1898. Narrated by David Ogden Stiers.

results.title: [William Dobell]
results.brief_description: On the tranquil shores of Lake Macquarie, William Dobell lives and works. He and Dame Mary Gilmore discuss his work and its development - rough sketches from real life later translated to danvas; commissioned portraits; and landscapes. Studies of some of his better known works are included. Contains some b&w footage.

results.title: Melbourne (no. 4)
results.brief_description:
General shots (rushes) of Melbourne ‘life’ from the 50s. All images very iconic and nostalgic.

Section 1. Several shots of daffodils in a park. Nice colour, long shots.

Section 2. Shots in a park near the Yarra looking towards the city.

Section 3. Shots of Fitzroy gardens, conservatory and Government House.

Section 4. Shots of large houses in Toorak.

Section 5. ANZAC day march in the city. Many people involved.

results.title: RMIT AIM Collection 1994
results.brief_description:
Compilation of student work from the University of RMIT Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) Department. 1994.
The Centre for Animation and Interactive Media, its courses, facilities, staff and collection of work was transferred from Swinburne University of Technology to RMIT University in 1995.
